pullsbody:
This removes a Node-specific dependency from the packge, allowing its
use in a browser context (via webpack or the like).

This is a breaking change for users of SNTP, but the change is
straightforward.  For those using this functionality, note that
@hapi/sntp is no longer maintained.
pull_commit_message:
Do not require @hapi/sntp anymore

This removes a Node-specific dependency from the packge, allowing its
use in a browser context (via webpack or the like).

This is a breaking change for users of SNTP, but the change is
straightforward.  For those using this functionality, note that
@hapi/sntp is no longer maintained.

pullsbody: This removes the Hapi plugin, fixing #272.  My understanding is that this causes no issues, as anyone using the existing Hapi plugin is using something unsupported anyway -- they wouldn't be using any changes that might be made in this repo.

pullsbody:
I'm getting an error when using a default strategy:
`Cannot read property 'payload' of undefined`
in the case where no **auth** object is defined in route options because a default strategy is declared

Searching for a solution, i found that [Stackoverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/57055801/hawk-authentication-error-with-hapi-hawk) related to the same error.

So i just changed the particular line.

pullsbody:
This PR bumps the `hoek` dependency version from `2.x.x` to `4.x.x`.  This fixes a [security vulnerability](https://snyk.io/vuln/npm:hoek:20180212) in `hoek`.  The vulnerability fix was backported into `hoek@4.x.x` in [this PR](https://github.com/hapijs/hoek/pull/231).

NOE: This PR's base fork is the `v3.1.x` branch; as you mentioned in #234, the mainline's dependency range remains secure.

NOTE: The latest version of `hoek` is `5.0.3`.  However, `Hoek.nextTick` was removed in [this commit](https://github.com/hapijs/hoek/commit/5f7e4dea1fec7cb58bf3eaa73ff4fc04bdb8e62d#diff-6d186b954a58d5bb740f73d84fe39073L851), so I have opted to only upgrade to `hoek@4.x.x` to avoid that breaking change.

Thank you for your time.

We use `codecov` at [webpack-cli](https://github.com/webpack/webpack-cli) which depends on request which in turn relies on the hawk library and the snp library. We got a security notification:

https://snyk.io/org/ev1stensberg/project/c57134c0-62a8-425e-9bcc-5ea87d69872f?disclosure=all&severity=high&severity=medium&severity=low

https://snyk.io/vuln/npm:hoek:20180212

The fix for https://github.com/babel/minify/issues/594 was released in https://github.com/babel/minify/releases/tag/gulp-babel-minify%400.3.0

closes #223

pulltitle: Browser authentication function accepts callback as fifth argument
pullsbody:
This makes the signature of the browser authentication function a "equivalent" to the [client authenticate function](https://github.com/hueniverse/hawk/blob/v6.0.1/lib/client.js#L149) and allows Oz/lib/client to use it in the browser [as partially discussed here](https://github.com/hueniverse/oz/issues/53#issuecomment-300639336).

I don't know if this is of interest, if so I'll happily write some tests.

Thanks for the bounty of amazing libraries @hueniverse !
pull_commit_message:
Browser authentication function accepts callback as fifth argument

This makes its signature a superset of the client authenticate
function and allows Oz/lib/client to use it in the browser.

pullsbody: Currently README is broken on npm because of these HTML tags.

The npm payload delivered from `npm install hawk` contains a bunch of things which are not needed for the module to actually work. By specifying an [`.npmignore` file](https://docs.npmjs.com/misc/developers#keeping-files-out-of-your-package), we can keep things out of the package to improve download times. Here is the data for your package:

|  | Including deps | Excluding deps |
| :-: | :-: | :-: |
| Current | 844 KB | 456 KB |
| Updated | 572 KB | 184 KB |
| **Savings** | **32.22%** | **59.65%** |

_I got these numbers using `du -sh <directory>`_

The difference between the "Including / Excluding deps" columns is whether or not the `node_modules/` directory containing `hawk`'s dependencies is included.

In case you want to double check the resulting package, you can do so locally:

```
# Create a tarball of the resulting package
$ npm pack

# See the file list of that tarball
$ tar -tf hawk-<version>.tgz
package/package.json
package/README.md
package/LICENSE
package/client.js
package/dist/browser.js
package/lib/browser.js
package/lib/client.js
package/lib/crypto.js
package/lib/index.js
package/lib/server.js
package/lib/utils.js

# Install the tarball as a local node module
$ npm install hawk-<version>.tgz
```
Happened to see this while reading the readme

Fixes the bower build. Issue #167

Because of the way bower works we have to add the built client file `dist/browser.js` under version control.

The other issue is that since bower can only work against git repos (no package server as in npm), it has to use git tags to figure out version numbers. Therefore I bumped the version in `package.json` and added the corresponding tag to my own forked repo. If this is merged the same tag should be added to main repo.

I noticed that `hawk` repo already uses tags for each version bump so there should be no problems with bower going forward.

Fixes the bower build. Issue #167

Because of the way bower works we have to add the built client file `dist/browser.js` under version control.

The other issue is that since bower can only work against git repos (no package server as in npm), it has to use git tags to figure out version numbers. Therefore I bumped the version in `package.json` and added the corresponding tag to my own forked repo. If this is merged the same tag should be added to main repo.

I noticed that `hawk` repo already uses tags for each version bump so there should be no problems with bower going forward.

pulltitle: Fix minor DoS attack on long headers or uris.
pullsbody:
Replaces #170

This PR, which is really just this [commit](https://github.com/hueniverse/hawk/commit/ccebde4b24d06014ac573888a21813b29a4a16c7) fixes the DoS attack that was merged into 4.x code, but applies it to the 3.x code. 

This seemed important specifically because [request](https://npmjs.org/request) relies on hawk@3.x and have [said they're not ready to drop node < 4 support](https://github.com/request/request/issues/2020) (which would come via hawk@4).

So this patch will offer a 3.1.x version that has the vuln fixed, which should allow request to update their dependencies.

This particular [patch](https://github.com/Snyk/vulndb/tree/3997877197b75c7e41c9eac1825040cf2246597b/data/npm/hawk/20160119) was generated for [Snyk](https://snyk.io) users, but we'd rather see users be able to do updates over patches in their remediation.

I hope this patch will be considered and merge (for release to 3.1.3). Thanks!
pull_commit_message:
Fix minor DoS attack on long headers or uris.

Related to #168

Supports the fix on the 3.x branch allowing for https://github.com/request/request to pick up the fix in 3.1.x

Fixes request/request#2020

pulltitle: adding support for receiving credentials.key during server-side nonce verification
pullsbody:
This is a possible implementation to support the behavior mentioned in #140. It'd be a lot cleaner if we didn't have to deal with backwards compatibility for existing clients using the current 'nonceFunc' interface, but I thought this would be the safest approach. Better to err on the side of caution, than inadvertently break everyone's nonce checking.

(sorry about the whitespace changes)

pullsbody:
I have seen quite some implementations on top of this library that do not perform any nonce checking.
Are there any objections to implement this within the library?
This pull request consists of a very primitive attempt :)
With this, I am hoping to prevent some trivial replay attacks and am looking forward to any kind of feedback.
If this here gets positive feedback, I'm inclined to handle timestamp checks prior to the nonce (baiscally move it out of the nonceFunction errback in lines 211-226 and execute it before line 209).

Tests missing, but I'm happy to spend some additional cycles on it, if this whole nonce thing is generally acceptable to you.
Browsers complain when lib/browser.js is included, because `module` is undefined. Add type checking to resolve this.
pull_commit_message:
Fix 'undefined module' error in lib/browser.js

Browsers complain when lib/browser.js is included, because `module` is undefined. Add type checking to resolve this.

pulltitle: using correct undefined check for global module variable
pullsbody:
Without this change, browsers (such as chrome) raise a ReferenceError on this line.

```
Uncaught ReferenceError: module is not defined browser.js:552
(anonymous function)
```

An alternative fix would be

```
if (window.module && module.exports) {
    module.exports = hawk;
}
```
pull_commit_message: using correct undefined check for global module variable

https://github.com/hueniverse/hawk/issues/111

https://github.com/hueniverse/hawk/blob/master/lib/browser.js#L146

```
    /*
        request:    object created via 'new XMLHttpRequest()' after response received
        artifacts:  object recieved from header().artifacts
        options: {
            payload:    optional payload received
            required:   specifies if a Server-Authorization header is required. Defaults to 'false'
        }
    */
```

s/recieved/received/

pulltitle: Fix time calculation. Stop clearing offset when setting storage.
pullsbody:
Hawk was trying to access the local offset from `localStorage` before any storage was set and therefore replaced the previous (correct) value with 0 which makes the next request fail.

Also, the local offset was added to the timestamp in milliseconds although it's in seconds resulting in failing requests even if the offset value was technically correct. I moved all the offset calculations to `hawk.utils.now` so that the division can be done at the right time.
pull_commit_message: Fix time calculation. Stop clearing offset when setting storage.

pullsbody:
I encountered an error with `client.authenticate`. I tried to use the function in the browser inside a browserify bundle. The error is thrown in browser.js:157:
`Uncaught TypeError: Object [object Object] has no method 'getResponseHeader'`.  `[object Object]` referes to the request object.
I figured that's because hawk assumes `request` to be the native xhr object. When using browserify, a node like request object will be passed to the function. The problem is that the node equivalent function to `getResponseHeader` is called `getHeader`. I fixed that by checking which function is available.

I encountered an error with `client.authenticate`. I tried to use the function in the browser inside a browserify bundle. The error is thrown in browser.js:157:
`Uncaught TypeError: Object [object Object] has no method 'getResponseHeader'`.  `[object Object]` referes to the request object.
I figured that's because hawk assumes `request` to be the native xhr object. When using browserify, a node like request object will be passed to the function. The problem is that the node equivalent function to `getResponseHeader` is called `getHeader`. I fixed that by checking which function is available.
Resync

pullsbody:
In order to support ie8 we replaced instances of:

``` javascript
Date.now
```

with

``` javascript
(new Date()).getTime()
```

(see http://kangax.github.io/es5-compat-table/#Date.now)

and

``` javascript
string.trim()
```

with

``` javascript
string.replace(/^\s+|\s+$/g, '')
```

(see http://kangax.github.io/es5-compat-table/#String.prototype.trim)

pull_commit_message: Putting this in the right place.

pullsbody: lib/browser.js is handy to put inside a script tag, not in a require system. I though it was easy enough to make it a  [component](http://component.io), and it helped me extend superagent and make a [handy http client abstraction](https://github.com/CrowdProcess/superagent-hawk) that works on the browser (don't know any other one currently).

pull_commit_message:
URI Fix

Fixed the URI used in the example so that if someone tries to follow along, like what I did and generate the HMAC to see if it is same as what is shown here.

pullsbody: Swapped dot slashes for `node ...`.
Swapped dot slashes for `node ...`.

The browser lib was generating the wrong authorization header and upon comparing with the nodejs client lib I noticed some inconsistencies, so I refactored it to reuse as much of the node version as possible which fixed the issue.

I have verified that the authorization header is being created properly and that the tests pass.

pulltitle: Actually HMAC the tsmac instead of just hashing it
pullsbody: Unless I'm missing something, the `tsmac` is supposed to be a MAC, not a plain digest.
pull_commit_message: Actually HMAC the tsmac instead of just hashing it

pullsbody:
Implementation as described in #58
Real testing would need to check if it actually persist across sessions but we can safely assume that if the value is accessible after being set, it will. Real testing would also include checking that on second session Hawk picks up the value from the LocalStorage.

pulltitle: Considerations for CORS requests on the browser
pullsbody: Explained why it may be necessary to use Access-Control-Expose-Headers when making CORS requests using Hawk.
pull_commit_message: Added browser considerations about CORS requests and headers

pullsbody: Checking for module existence produced "Uncaught ReferenceError: module is not defined". Checking if the type of module is not "undefined" fixes this problem.
pull_commit_message: Checking for module existence doesn't throw a ReferenceError anymore

pulltitle: artifacts.id is no longer required for generating a response header
pull_commit_message: artifacts.id is no longer required for generating a response header
